posts.title: React2Shell CVE-2025-55182
posts.summary: Critical RCE vulnerability in React & Next.js, CVSS 10.0, enabling unauthenticated remote code execution.
posts.content: Technical breakdown of CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell), a critical remote code execution vulnerability affecting React Server Components and Next.js applications.
posts.descriptiot:
React2Shell CVE-2025-55182

Introduction

Modern web development just faced its Log4Shell moment. On December 3, 2025, a critical security vulnerability in React Server Components (RSC) was publicly disclosed: CVE-2025-55182, nicknamed React2Shell. The vulnerability enables unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) against servers running vulnerable React and Next.js applications with a CVSS score of 10.0.

This bug allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands on servers using a single crafted HTTP request — no credentials, no special configuration, and no default logging indicators.

Why This Is So Dangerous

React Server Components (introduced in React 19) allow parts of applications to render on the server for improved performance and smaller client bundles. However, the architecture relies on streaming serialized payloads over the React Flight protocol.

A flaw in the deserialization logic allows malicious payloads to:

  • Manipulate JavaScript prototypes
  • Resolve dangerous Node.js modules such as child_process
  • Trigger functions capable of executing system commands

The vulnerable execution path centers around a function named requireModule().

Exploitation in the Wild

This vulnerability was exploited within hours of disclosure. Threat intelligence teams observed active exploitation from China-aligned groups including Earth Lamia and Jackpot Panda.

Captured attacks included:

  • Credential harvesting through dumping .env files
  • Host reconnaissance using whoami, uname, and id
  • Persistence attempts by writing malicious files under /tmp/

Public proof-of-concept exploits were released on GitHub on December 4–5, achieving full success against default create-next-app installations.

Mitigation

  • Immediately upgrade to patched React and Next.js versions
  • Disable exposed React Server Component endpoints if not required
  • Restrict server execution permissions
  • Implement runtime monitoring for abnormal module loading

Conclusion

React2Shell demonstrates how serialization and deserialization flaws can introduce catastrophic server-side vulnerabilities. Organizations must treat server component architectures as part of their critical attack surface and apply strict input validation and dependency management practices.

posts.title: Hackers Exploiting Sneeit Framework Plugin Vulnerability
posts.summary: Active exploitation targeting a vulnerability in the Sneeit Framework plugin.
posts.description: Security analysis of an actively exploited vulnerability affecting the Sneeit Framework WordPress plugin.
posts.content:
Sneeit Framework Plugin Vulnerability

Overview

Hackers are actively exploiting a vulnerability in the Sneeit Framework plugin affecting WordPress-based websites.

Impact

Successful exploitation may allow attackers to manipulate website content or gain unauthorized access.

Mitigation

  • Update the plugin immediately
  • Audit administrator accounts
  • Monitor for unusual file changes

Conclusion

Website administrators should treat plugin vulnerabilities as critical and apply patches promptly.

posts.description: Technical explanation of IDOR vulnerabilities and mitigation strategies.
posts.content:
IDOR Vulnerabilities

Overview

IDOR vulnerabilities occur when applications expose internal object references without proper authorization checks.

Prevention

  • Implement proper access control
  • Validate user permissions server-side

Conclusion

Access control failures remain a top OWASP risk.

Broken Access Control

Overview

Broken access control remains one of the most exploited vulnerability classes.

Mitigation

  • Enforce server-side authorization checks

Conclusion

Access control must be validated at every layer.

posts.content:
Server-Side Template Injection

Overview

SSTI occurs when untrusted user input is embedded into server-side templates without proper sanitization.

Impact

Exploitation may lead to remote code execution.

Conclusion

Template engines must never evaluate untrusted input.
